title: Domain 2.2: Compare and contrast wireless security protocols and authentication methods.
content:
ðŸ”’ Protocols and Encryption

  • WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2): Uses AES encryption; strong security for wireless networks. Still widely used but being replaced by WPA3.
  • WPA3: Improved version of WPA2. Stronger encryption, better protection against brute-force attacks, and improved public network security.
  • TKIP (Temporal Key Integrity Protocol): Older encryption used with WPA. Considered insecure and deprecated in modern networks.
  • AES (Advanced Encryption Standard): Symmetric encryption used in WPA2/WPA3. Provides strong data confidentiality.

ðŸ”‘ Authentication Methods

  • RADIUS: Centralized protocol for Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA). Common in enterprise Wi-Fi networks.
  • TACACS+: More secure AAA protocol than RADIUS. Used for managing access to network devices like routers/switches.
  • Kerberos: Ticket-based network authentication. Uses symmetric encryption and is standard in enterprise domains (like Windows AD).
  • Multifactor Authentication (MFA): Requires two or more factors: something you know (password), have (device), or are (biometrics).
